content:
Mathlib does not have basic numerical analysis theorems. For example, the forward Euler method is not defined. In https://github.com/Vilin97/forward_euler I defined it and proved that it converges to the true solution as the time step shrinks. I used a strong assumption that the RHS of the ODE is globally bounded -- it can be relaxed with some extra work but I first want to understand if there is interest in this kind of work.

I split the formalization into two PRs. One has nothing to do with the Euler method, and is just about regular grids and linear interpolation. The second PR is about the forward Euler method specifically.

For transparency, this is my first time making heavy use of Claude Code for a mathlib PR. The initial version of the formalization was done by Aristotle, and then I went through many (20+) iterations of factoring out lemmas, golfing, simplifying proofs using Claude Code. I do believe that the final code is reasonably high quality -- probably higher than if I was writing it myself. The initial formalization took Aristotle 2 hours, and I spent ~12 hours iterating on it with Claude Code.
